#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Red
#Text=Cross is not in New Orleans for Katrina , Guard raced it to Superdome
#Text=Saturday , September 10 , 2005
#Text=The American Red Cross is not lending its usual assistance in New Orleans , because the Louisiana National Guard acted first .
#Text=After Saturday September 3 , it was agreed with state officials the Red Cross was not needed because the large-scale evacuation of the city was under way .
#Text=The organization explains on its web site :
#Text=Access to New Orleans is controlled by the National Guard and local authorities and while we are in constant contact with them , we simply cannot enter New Orleans against their orders .
#Text=The state Homeland Security Department had requested -- and continues to request -- that the American Red Cross not come back into New Orleans following the hurricane .
#Text=Our presence would keep people from evacuating and encourage others to come into the city .
#Text=The Red Cross does not conduct search and rescue operations .
#Text=We are an organization of civilian volunteers and cannot get relief aid into any location until the local authorities say it is safe and provide us with security and access .
#Text=The original plan was to evacuate all the residents of New Orleans to safe places outside the city .
#Text=With the hurricane bearing down , the city government decided to open a shelter of last resort in the Superdome downtown .
#Text=We applaud this decision and believe it saved a significant number of lives .
#Text=On September 1 , the Red Cross offered to Louisiana state officials to enter New Orleans , who rejected the offer due to logistical difficulties .

#Text=Making the offer the next day to Col. Jay Mayeaux , the deputy director of the Louisiana Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness , the Red Cross was asked to wait 24 hours while preparations were made .
#Text=By the next day , Saturday September 3rd , the National Guard had arrived in the city , felt they had adequate supplies and did not need the Red Cross .
#Text=Superdome : refuge of last resort
#Text=The American Red Cross is often involved in emergency situations , and the term applied to the Superdome , " refuge of last resort " , is based on Red Cross shelter standards .
#Text=It is the minimal type of shelter , defined primarily by not meeting shelter standards :
#Text=May or may not meet any of the ARC criteria for a shelter and has not been approved for use as a shelter by the ARC .
#Text=May be located either inside or outside of the Hurricane Risk Area .
#Text=Physical features required : Located outside of the flood zone or ability to locate on floors elevated above flood potential area and hurricane wind resistant structure .
#Text=Ticking clock
#Text=Despite the Superdome being a minimal shelter , it was reported there were 26,000 people there .
#Text=As the Times-Picayune reported on Sunday , August 28 , Col. Mayeaux was involved in preparations :
#Text=" To help keep them fed and hydrated , the Louisiana National Guard delivered three truckloads of water and seven truckloads of MREs — short for " meals ready to eat .
#Text=" That 's enough to supply 15,000 people for three days , according to Col. Jay Mayeaux , deputy director of the Department of Homeland Security 's Office of Emergency Preparedness .
